latestAction.text: Referred to the Subcommittee on Crime, Terrorism, Homeland Security, and Investigations.
Read twice and referred to the Committee on Environment and Public Works.

item.latestTitle: Hunting, Fishing, and Recreational Shooting Protection Act

bill.constitutionalAuthorityStatementText: By Mr. MILLER of Florida:H.R. 322.Congress has the power to enact this legislation pursuantto the following:Amendment II to The Constitution of the United States[Page H178]

item.title: Hunting, Fishing, and Recreational Shooting Protection Act

To amend the Toxic Substances Control Act to clarify the jurisdiction of the Environmental Protection Agency with respect to certain sporting good articles, and to exempt those articles from a definition under that Act.
Hunting, Fishing, and Recreational Shooting Protection Act

item.text: Hunting, Fishing, and Recreational Shooting Protection Act - Amends the Toxic Substances Control Act (TSCA) to exclude from the definition of "chemical substance" for purposes of such Act: (1) any component of  any pistol, revolver, firearm, shell, or cartridge the sale of which is subject to federal excise tax, including shot, bullets and other projectiles, propellants, and primers; and (2) any sport fishing equipment the sale of which is subject to federal excise tax and sport fishing equipment components.
item.name: Introduced in House

item.text: Referred to the Subcommittee on Environment and the Economy.
Referred to the House Committee on Energy and Commerce.

bill.title: Hunting, Fishing, and Recreational Shooting Protection Act

latestAction.text: Referred to the Subcommittee on Environment and the Economy.

dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.
dublinCore.dc:contributor: Congressional Research Service, Library of Congress
dublinCore.dc:description: This file contains bill summaries and statuses for federal legislation. A bill summary describes the most significant provisions of a piece of legislation and details the effects the legislative text may have on current law and federal programs. Bill summaries are authored by the Congressional Research Service (CRS) of the Library of Congress. As stated in Public Law 91-510 (2 USC 166 (d)(6)), one of the duties of CRS is "to prepare summaries and digests of bills and resolutions of a public general nature introduced in the Senate or House of Representatives". For more information, refer to the User Guide that accompanies this file.
